description: From Middle English scet, schat, from Old English sceatt (“property, goods, owndom, wealth, treasure; payment, price, gift, bribe, tax, tribute, money, goods, reward, rent, a tithe; a piece of money, a coin; denarius, twentieth part of a shilling”) and Old Norse skattr (“wealth, treaure, tax, tribute, coin”); both from Proto-Germanic *skattaz (“cattle, kine, wealth, owndom, goods, hoard, treasure, geld, money”), from Proto-Indo-European *skatn-, *skat- (“to jump, skip, splash out”). Cognate with Scots scat (“tax, levy, charge, payment, bribe”), West Frisian skat (“treasure, darling”), Dutch schat (“treasure, hoard, darling, sweetheart”), German Schatz (“treasure, hoard, wealth, store, darling, sweetheart”), Swedish skatt (“treasure, tax, duty”), Icelandic skattur (“tax, tribute”), Latin scateō (“gush, team, bubble forth, abound”).

entries.meaning: (UK dialectal) A land-tax paid in the Shetland Islands.

description: Origin uncertain. Both the Oxford English Dictionary and Merriam-Webster suggest derivation from Ancient Greek σκῶρ (skôr, “excrement”), compare English scato-, but Random House Dictionary suggests that the popular character of the word makes this unlikely. Perhaps from English dialectal scat (“to scatter, fling, bespatter”), or an alteration of shit, which is also used for "drugs, heroin".

examples: Wherever legitimate tracks are found there's always some fresh scat, y'know, poo, flop, dumplings.
Enema queens, like scat queens, are really the scum of the earth.

entries.meaning: (UK, dialect) A brisk shower of rain, driven by the wind.

verbs.description: scat (third-person singular simple present scats, present participle scatting, simple past and past participle scatted)

entries.meaning: (music, jazz) To sing an improvised melodic solo using nonsense syllables, often onomatopoeic or imitative of musical instruments.

description: From scoot, from the root of shoot. Alternatively, from the expression quicker than scat (“in a great hurry”), perhaps representing a hiss followed by the word cat. Compare Swedish schas (“shoo, begone”).

verbs.description: scat (third-person singular simple present scats, present participle scatting, simple past and past participle scatted)

examples: Here comes the principal; we'd better scat.

description: From the taxonomic name of the family.

entries.meaning: Any fish in the family Scatophagidae
